title: Who knows what font this is from nas illmatic album ??
author: morellothedon

comments.content:
It's calligraphic blackletter--the kind of writing found in manuscripts/books before the advent of movable type--and most likely hand-drawn.

There are dozens of digital versions out there (Old English being one, but it is more ornamented than your sample). These get you close:

[http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/bella-rose/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327015243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/bella-rose/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/fontmesa/bella-rose/")  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lamatas/liturgisch/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327015243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/lamatas/liturgisch/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/lamatas/liturgisch/")
Mmmm.. it's gettin' close but not really close, anyway, thankyou kthomps5
As I said, the original was hand-drawn, based on this type of lettering--not every logo is hatched directly from a font file.
Yea i know what you mean.. it was originally drawn, that's right !! Thankyou for your time and support grts

This is indeed Old English, with  
1. width compressed to about 65%,  
2. made thicker by a parallel line technique,  
3. the letters packed together so that they overlap  
4. the \_s\_ simplified and edited, particularly so that the lower lhs would line up with the tail on \_a\_.

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327015243im_/http:/typophile.com/files/OldEnglishWidthAt65Percent_4194.jpg)
  [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/old-english-text/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327015243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/old-english-text/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mti/old-english-text/")  
Don

No need to edit the \_s\_ from Old English.  
This is the \_s\_ from Notre Dame with width compressed to about 65%,

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327015243im_/http:/typophile.com/files/NotreDame_s_Width65Percent_3546.gif)
  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/notre-dame/](http://web.archive.org/web/20150327015243/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/notre-dame/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/linotype/notre-dame/") You merely need to make it thicker by a parallel line technique.  
Don
